author: pauld.9606
content: What happens when a stateless block is propagated, but the block witness is incomplete?

author: pauld.9606
content: That is, the miner forgot to include a leaf in the witness, but the witness still merkleizes to the correct root, and most transactions can still be processed.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> Presumably that block gets ignored and does not get propagated?

author: pauld.9606
content: Yes, the simple (and perhaps best) option is to make it an invalid block.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> I guess if a node in the middle happens to be stateful it could just fix the witness

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <alexberegszaszi> If the "canonical witness" idea (= canonical witness hash in the block) is implemented, then such blocks would be just plain invalid and there would be no possibility to "fix" it.

author: pipermerriam
content: Assuming we can satisfy the various prerequisites, the canonical witness approach seems like the best way to address any issues with incomplete or bloated witnesses

author: pauld.9606
content: Yes, bloated witnesses are also interesting.

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> Question: have we looked at the benefits of hash of witness vs hash of access list?

author: eth2_gitter_bot
content: <vbuterin> If you have the access list of the block then you can verify the witness, which is just hashing, and see if it is correct

author: pipermerriam
content: <@273808422753796097> no, but it's probably very good for us to examine the different ways that we want to use witnesses and make sure that whatever hashing scheme we choose is good at supporting those. Merklization/hashing of the access list might work well and be a nice tree structure independent way to do it.
